info.game_comments:
1998 Boston Week game 2.
From the Wang Center for the Performing Arts in Boston, Massachusetts.

(1, 1).clue: He sketched out a model of his telegraph during an ocean voyage in 1832

(2, 1).clue: In New Zealand, a pakeha is a person who isn't descended from these natives

(4, 1).clue: Instrument you're most likely to hear at the Braemar Gathering & other Highland Games

(5, 1).clue: The father of "ER"'s Julianna Margulies wrote this product's "Plop, Plop, Fizz, Fizz" jingle

(6, 1).clue: A stick used for punishment; don't "spare" it

(1, 2).clue: Eli Whitney saw little profit from this invention as unauthorized copies sprouted up everywhere

(2, 2).clue: Corfiotes are natives of this island that isn't far from Albania

(4, 2).clue: Musical instrument ineptly played by private Hannibal Dobbs on the TV series "F Troop"

(5, 2).clue: (Hi, I'm Carol Burnett.)  On TV I first pulled on my left ear as a way of saying hello to this relative who was at home

(6, 2).clue: It's the past participle of "shoe", & we're not horsing around

(1, 3).clue: John Fitch launched a vessel of this type in 1787, 16 years before Robert Fulton

(2, 3).clue: Orcadians don't live on the planet Ork but in the Orkney Islands of this British Isles country

(4, 3).clue: This percussion instrument with small jingling disks is often used to provide a gypsy effect in musical pieces

(5, 3).clue: Her mother originated the column of household hints that she took over at age 26 in 1977

(6, 3).clue: To poke, perhaps with a cattle implement

(1, 4).clue: To demonstrate his safety brake, this inventor jumped in an elevator & cut the cables

(2, 4).clue: The people of this "Magnolia State" are sometimes known as Mud-Cats

(4, 4).clue: The lowest-pitched of the brass instruments, its name is from the Latin for trumpet

(5, 4).clue: This actor & his brother Brett played brothers Larry & Jimmy Flynt in 1996's "The People vs. Larry Flynt"

(6, 4).clue: A style once worn in swingin' London, or Peggy Lipton's "Squad"

(1, 5).clue: He launched the first liquid propellant rocket in 1926 at his Aunt Effie's Massachusetts farm

(2, 5).clue: It's the religion of most of the Uzbeks in Uzbekistan

(5, 5).clue: This TV comic's mother Betty is a spokesperson for the Human Rights Campaign, a national gay rights group

(6, 5).clue: Perhaps from obsolete Dutch for "shred", it's a young cod or haddock

(1, 1).clue: One of Hawthorne's last works, "Chiefly About War Matters", was chiefly about this war

(2, 1).clue: In Sanskrit this speedy animal's name was chitraka, meaning "speckled"

(3, 1).clue: 20th Century Fox oddly chose the month of June to release this 1947 fable about Kris Kringle

(4, 1).clue: Holly Joan Hart, this magazine's April 1998 centerfold, likes F. Scott Fitzgerald & bubble baths

(5, 1).clue: Minnie Driver, Scott Wolf & LeAnn Rimes are among celebrities who've confessed to doing this in the shower

(6, 1).clue: A replica of the Mayflower is docked on the waterfront of this Massachusetts city

(1, 2).clue: Hawthorne added this letter to his last name when he began writing stories

(2, 2).clue: Discovered & decimated in less than 200 years, its name is from the Portuguese for "foolish"

(3, 2).clue: He directed Judy Garland in "Meet Me In St. Louis" & married her the next year

(4, 2).clue: In 1789 the first of these events took place in April; it was later moved to March, then January

(5, 2).clue: This type of enclosure for showering shares its name with a home for horses

(6, 2).clue: Samoset stunned the Pilgrims when he welcomed them to America in this language

(1, 3).clue: Hawthorne based "The Celestial Railroad" on this John Bunyan work, one of his boyhood favorites

(2, 3).clue: These colorful beetles were named in honor of the Virgin Mary

(3, 3).clue: He was the subject of the 1946 biopic seen here:"You see, tomorrow I leave for Hollywood, according to what they call 'talking pictures', so what's going to happen to me?"

(4, 3).clue: 2 American car models, or the 2 signs of the Zodiac that cover parts of April

(5, 3).clue: The name of this thin mortar that seals tiles can also refer to meal or malt

(6, 3).clue: No Puritan, this friend of Myles Standish was the last surviving signer of The Mayflower Compact

(1, 4).clue: Mrs. Hawthorne's nickname for this family friend & novelist was "Mr. Omoo"

(2, 4).clue: The story goes Capt. Cook asked what that animal was & a local replied this, meaning "Don't understand"

(3, 4).clue: The title of this Boyer-Bergman film became a verb meaning to make someone doubt his sanity

(4, 4).clue: It's the 1991 film about 4 women who share an Italian villa for a month

(5, 4).clue: In 1993 this Teledyne brand produced its 40 millionth shower massage unit

(1, 5).clue: Hawthorne died while traveling through New Hampshire with this former president, his close friend

(2, 5).clue: This name for the spiny anteater is from the Greek for "viper"; it has a venom system

(3, 5).clue: Don't look for a mail carrier in this 1946 crime flick--he's only a metaphor

(4, 5).clue: April 5 is the feast day of St. Vincent Ferrer, patron of these workers, like Sir Thomas Crapper

(5, 5).clue: A squirting shower head may be clogged with this--the calcium compound, not the fruit

(0, 0).clue: Native New Englander seen here, modeling for his company's catalog sometime before WWI
